Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Library Based Design of Linked Equilibria to Control Protein Interactions

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Antibodies play an important role in the immune response by recognizing foreign molecules with high affinity and specificity. It is these same properties that make them excellent affinity reagents in fields ranging from basic research to diagnostics and nanotechnology. While efforts to obtain high affinity antibodies against almost any molecule of interest are now relatively straight-forward, methods to control and regulate antibody binding have not been well explored. Regulation of protein interactions is quite common in biology and frequently involves additional equilibria that are linked to protein binding. The research objective of this CAREER project is to study single domain antibody fragments as a vehicle for understanding and applying linked equilibria in biomolecular systems. By combining recent advances in protein engineering techniques with biophysical and structural analysis, this research will explore several methods to engineer reversible control of antibody interactions through the introduction of linked equilibria. Several approaches will be explored to either reduce or enhance antibody binding under defined conditions. The resulting knowledge, methods, and reagents will help stimulate new directions in research and biotechnology by providing unique routes to control protein interactions. These results will also be of fundamental interest to researchers interested in protein design, structure/function relationships, and computational chemistry. Furthermore, these results will help improve the general understanding and teaching of molecular regulation in biology.

Broader Impacts: The educational component complements the research aims and serves to enhance training at Northern Illinois University (NIU) and the regional community. To enhance the undergraduate curriculum at NIU, an upper-level undergraduate biochemistry lab will be re-designed to incorporate inquiry-based learning approaches. These training tools will be further developed through the initiation of a web-based wiki project to serve as a training resource for the larger community of biochemical instructors and students. To help attract and retain student interest in the sciences at NIU, a new course will be developed that is aimed at exposing undergraduate students to cutting edge research at the interface of biology and chemistry. In collaboration with NIU STEM Outreach, this course will also be adapted to summer workshops for pre-college students and secondary school instructors to help increase scientific literacy. This CAREER project also includes partnerships with NIU's STEM Outreach and Latino Resource Center to provide opportunities for high school students and underrepresented undergraduate students, respectively, to perform research in the PI's laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overall Outcome: This project created new methods to design biological molecules with enhanced properties.

Antibodies, a type of protein produced by the body’s immune response, act by tightly binding foreign molecules to help eliminate pathogens. Beyond their important physiological role, antibodies are indispensable to a large number of life science fields, including cell and molecular biology, molecular imaging, medicine, and nanotechnology. Due to their ability to discriminate differences in target molecules, antibodies are used in a wide-range of applications from fundamental biological studies to diagnostics (e.g. environmental contamination detection). Traditionally, animal-based immunization is used to generate antibodies that recognize a specific target molecule. The ability to produce billions of unique antibodies with man-made diversity in test tubes has opened new pathways in antibody design. These man-made antibodies can be engineered with unique functions that are not possible with conventional antibodies. Specifically, the project investigated new directions in the design of antibody and protein interactions through the generation of antibody (protein) switches. Due to the strong attraction an antibody possesses for its target, most antibody interactions may be considered a one-way event; however antibody switches are capable of reversible (on/off) interactions. The interaction between the antibody switch and the target molecule may be turned on and off through environmental conditions, such as changes in pH or the amount of metal ion present, which serves as the molecular “light switch.” The methods used to produce these switches are robust and transferable to other protein reagents and will help stimulate new directions in research and biotechnology through the ability to reversibly control interactions at the molecular level. In addition, the engineered antibodies have served as models that have improved our understanding of molecular recognition.

The project provided training opportunities for over 20 individuals in the PI’s research group. Five PhD students participated in this project, which contributed to their advancement to positions as postdoctoral researchers, college instructors, or industry scientists. Furthermore, more than 15 undergraduate research students, high school students and high school teachers participated on the project during the academic year or summer. Participants included those from traditionally underrepresented groups (~25% African American or Hispanic and ~50% women). These opportunities to participate in the research played an important role in retaining these students and their interest in research and teaching careers. The PI and his lab regularly participated in summer STEM camp outreach efforts by offering hands-on workshops (to 20-30 high school students) introducing biochemical research and the roles proteins play in biological systems. In addition, the PI developed an inquiry-based upper-level biochemistry lab course module that provides undergraduate biochemistry students an opportunity to experience student-driven scientific inquiry. Students have ranked this module as a highlight of the class. As the experience mirrors realistic biochemical problems, the experience helps better prepare students for the job market and graduate/professional programs.
